original_data.question: A 60-year-old man comes to the physician for a routine physical examination. He lives in a group home and takes no medications. During the appointment, he frequently repeats the same information and needs to be reminded why he is at the doctor's office. He says that he is a famous poet and recently had a poem published in a national magazine. His vital signs are within normal limits. He has a constricted affect. Neurological examination shows no focal deficits. On mental status examination, he has no long-term memory deficits and is able to count in serial sevens without error. An MRI of the brain shows atrophy of the anterior thalami and small mamillary bodies. Which of the following is the most likely predisposing factor for this patient's condition?

model_response:
This patient has Korsakoff syndrome, which is characterized by an anterograde amnesia, with relative preservation of other cognitive functions. It is caused by thiamine (vitamin B1) deficiency secondary to chronic alcohol use disorder. Thiamine is a cofactor for several enzymes, including those involved in glucose metabolism and neurotransmitter synthesis. The mamillary bodies are particularly sensitive to thiamine deficiency, and their atrophy is frequently seen in this disorder. Korsakoff syndrome is often associated with Wernicke encephalopathy, which is characterized by ataxia and ophthalmoplegia. The other listed choices are not associated with this syndrome. Consumption of undercooked meat can lead to a variety of neurological disorders, including Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease, which is characterized by rapidly progressive dementia and myoclonus. Chronic hypertension can lead to vascular dementia. Alcohol use disorder can lead to a variety of neurological disorders, including dementia, but not Korsakoff syndrome. Spirochete infections can lead to neurological disorders, including dementia (e.g., syphilis).

###Answer: OPTION C IS CORRECT.</s><s>

question_entities.definition: Human males as cultural, psychological, sociological, political, and economic entities.
Having a black or dark core or plug.
Individuals licensed to practice medicine.
Systematic and thorough inspection of the patient for physical signs of disease or abnormality.
Any number of entities (members) considered as a unit.
Aspects of peoples' living conditions that may and can impact people's health and/or well-being. These factors may be physical (e.g., housing quality) or social circumstances (e.g., living alone).
Drugs intended for human or veterinary use, presented in their finished dosage form. Included here are materials used in the preparation and/or formulation of the finished dosage form.
A meeting arranged with someone at a particular time and place.
Make or do or perform again.

Sender sends payload to addressee as information. Addressee does not have responsibilities beyond serving addressee's own interest (i.e., read and memorize if you see fit). This is equivalent to an FYI on a memo.
The room or rooms in which the physician and staff provide patient care. The offices include all rooms in the physician's office suite.

"The business or profession of the commercial production and issuance of literature" (Webster's 3d). It includes the publisher, publication processes, editing and editors. Production may be by conventional printing methods or by electronic publishing.

The feeling-tone accompaniment of an idea or mental representation. It is the most direct psychic derivative of instinct and the psychic representative of the various bodily changes by means of which instincts manifest themselves.
Assessment of sensory and motor responses and reflexes that is used to determine impairment of the nervous system.
A lack or deficiency.

A standardized and structured interview originally developed by Marshal Folstein, Susan Folstein and Paul McHugh (Journal of Psychiatric Research, 1975), which is used to evaluate an individual's cognitive function.
Involving or being in effect for a long time.
Deterioration in memory function.
Publication intended to be issued on an ongoing basis, generally more frequently than annually, containing separate articles, stories, or writings.
A discrepancy between a computed, observed, or measured value or condition and the true, specified, or theoretically correct value or condition.

Non-invasive method of demonstrating internal anatomy based on the principle that atomic nuclei in a strong magnetic field absorb pulses of radiofrequency energy and emit them as radiowaves which can be reconstructed into computerized images. The concept includes proton spin tomographic techniques.

The part of CENTRAL NERVOUS SYSTEM that is contained within the skull (CRANIUM). Arising from the NEURAL TUBE, the embryonic brain is comprised of three major parts including PROSENCEPHALON (the forebrain); MESENCEPHALON (the midbrain); and RHOMBENCEPHALON (the hindbrain). The developed brain consists of CEREBRUM; CEREBELLUM; and other structures in the BRAIN STEM.
Decrease in the size of a cell, tissue, organ, or multiple organs, associated with a variety of pathological conditions such as abnormal cellular changes, ischemia, malnutrition, or hormonal changes.
Of or involving the front of a main body.
Paired bodies containing mostly GRAY MATTER and forming part of the lateral wall of the THIRD VENTRICLE of the brain.
A pair of nuclei and associated GRAY MATTER in the interpeduncular space rostral to the posterior perforated substance in the POSTERIOR HYPOTHALAMUS.

Fundamental claims of patients, as expressed in statutes, declarations, or generally accepted moral principles. (Bioethics Thesaurus) The term is used for discussions of patient rights as a group of many rights, as in a hospital's posting of a list of patient rights.
A state of being, such as a state of health.
